ygData.msgSnippet: Source is here: https://archive-crawler.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/archive-crawler/trunk/hcc/ The NPE seems to indicate the mbeanServer has not been set:

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] many questions about hcc
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=202034705; y=WGhxYyzFo0QgPZ5aO1ppMPcB08T0tMaV6IJxl8xqGnYDvjWzOv98p14R

Source is here: 
https://archive-crawler.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/archive-crawler/trunk/hcc/

The NPE seems to indicate the mbeanServer has not been set: 
http://crawler.archive.org/hcc/xref/org/archive/hcc/ClusterControllerBean.html#831.  
This can happen if createMBeanServer finds nothing.  Do you have the JMX 
flags enabled for the JVM you are hosting hcc in?  (Or is hcc hosted in 
JBOSS?  If the latter, then there *should* be JMX servers available.)

Heritrix should be deregistering with JNDI each instance if its been a 
clean shutdown.  See 
http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/crawler/Heritrix.html#1545.  
See in same file the getJndiContainerName method which constructs the 
JNDI name per instance -- they take a similar format to names used 
registering with JMX.

The JNDI registry in JBOSS is RAM-based so with a controlled start/stop 
of JBOSS followed by startup and shutdown of Heritrix, you should see a 
Heritrix instance come and go in the JNDI registry (JBOSS MBean screen 
can be hard to navigate: you might search using a string like 
'org.archive.crawler:*').

There is no way currently to name the default Heritrix instance on the 
command line.

JNDI is used as a central place all Heritrix instances register 
themselves to.  hcc goes there to figure all members participating in 
the cluster.  The name of instances in JNDI includes the JMX address so 
hcc, once its found an instance in JNDI, subsequently knows where to 
send its JMX controlling operations.
 
If you are deploying Heritrix in JBOSS, then it provides the JMX Agent 
Heritrix will register itself with (and via which hcc will send JMX 
operations to get to the Heritrix instance).  Otherwise, enable the JMX 
settings on your JVM so Heritrix registers itself with the JVM JMX Agent.

HTH,
St.Ack


Andrea Goethals wrote:
>
> Hello,
>
> I've been trying for a few days to get hcc working but still am having
> trouble figuring out all the pieces. I've followed the hcc Overview
> page (http://crawler.archive.org/hcc/apidocs/index.html 
> <http://crawler.archive.org/hcc/apidocs/index.html>) and the
> emails we have about it from this list. I'm new to JBOSS and JMX but
> have gotten the JBOSS part of it working. I can start up JBOSS as a
> name service, start a heritrix instance up and then initialize an hcc
> ClusterControllerBean. After I call init() on the
> ClusterControllerBean I get a NullPointerException in my console:
>
> Starting ClusterControllerBean
> May 24, 2007 1:56:15 PM org.archive.hcc.ClusterControllerBean init
> INFO: maxPerContainer setting: 1
> May 24, 2007 1:56:15 PM org.archive.hcc.ClusterControllerBean$3 run
> INFO: running poll task...
> java.lang.NullPointerException
> at 
> org.archive.hcc.ClusterControllerBean.registerMBean(ClusterControllerBean.java:833)
> at 
> org.archive.hcc.ClusterControllerBean.init(ClusterControllerBean.java:817)
> at 
> edu.harvard.hul.ois.wax.crawl.CrawlController.main(CrawlController.java:44)
> Started ClusterControllerBean
> May 24, 2007 1:56:15 PM org.archive.hcc.ClusterControllerBean$3 run
> INFO: poll task done.
> May 24, 2007 1:57:15 PM org.archive.hcc.ClusterControllerBean$3 run
> INFO: running poll task...
>
> Besides getting help with this exception - how can I get the hcc
> source? It's not bundled with the heritrix src code and I only get the
> *.class files in the hcc jar from CruiseControl.
>
> I see this in JBOSS' JNDIView:
> +- org.archive.crawler (class: org.jnp.interfaces.NamingContext)
>
> Is this the Heritrix instance? Even when I stop my heritrix instance
> it still is listed in the JNDIView.
>
> Is there a way to name the heritrix crawler from the command line
> start-up? I saw that you can do this from the heritrix web GUI.
>
> Also, I'm having trouble understanding which ports are needed to get
> hcc & heritrix working. I need to change the default ports for JBOSS,
> hcc and heritrix to keep my used ports within a certain range on some
> overused machines. I have these set:
> * JNDI port set in JBOSS and in the jndi.properties accessible by all
> 3 of the ClusterControllerClient, ClusterControllerServer and the
> heritrix instances
> * Heritrix GUI port
> * JBOSS JMX Client ports
> Is the JNDI port all that the hcc and heritrix classes need or do they
> also need a JMX port? By using JBOSS for the name service does this
> mean we are using it for the JMX agent?
>
> Sorry about the number of questions here!
>
> thanks,
> Andrea
>
>
